sec.title: 21st Century Workplace Skills
sec.p: The National Academies of Science have defined what researchers, educators, and policymakers mean by deeper learning and 21st century competencies (Pellegrino et al., 2012). With deeper learning, students develop expertise in a particular domain or subject area and can take what was learned in one situation and apply it to new situations. Using the process of deeper learning, students develop 21st century competencies. The researchers used the broader term competencies rather than skills to include both knowledge and skills. The knowledge and skills generally fall into three categories: cognitive, interpersonal, and intrapersonal. Knowledge and skills that fall within the cognitive domain include critical thinking, reasoning, and related skills; those within the interpersonal domain include expressing information to others, interpreting others’ messages, and responding appropriately; and those within the intrapersonal domain include self-management. Although research on 21st century competencies is limited, emerging evidence suggests that cognitive, intrapersonal, and interpersonal knowledge and skills can be taught in ways that encourage transfer. Transfer is supported when instruction is organized around general principles and teachers instruct students about how, when, and why to apply this knowledge. Research-based teaching methods include using multiple and varied representations of concepts and tasks; encouraging elaboration, questioning, and explanation; engaging learners in challenging tasks; teaching with examples and cases; connecting topics to students’ personal lives and interests; attending to the knowledge and skills students are developing and their relevance, rather than grading; and using formative assessments that monitor students’ progress and provide feedback to teachers and students.

sec.title: School Is Easy for Students
sec.p: The Center for American Progress has reported that many students find that their schoolwork is just too easy. Using the 4th, 8th, and 12th grade background surveys of the 2009, 2010, and 2011 National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), Boser and Rosenthal (2012) reported these findings:

list-item.p: Large percentages of students report that their schoolwork is “too easy.” Across grade levels and subject matter areas, students report a lack of challenge: 21% of high school math students, 29% of eighth-grade math students, and 37% of fourth-grade math students, 56% of high school civics students, 51% of eighth-grade civics students, 55% of high school history students, and 57% of eighth-grade history students report that their schoolwork is too easy.

Students report that they are not engaged in rigorous learning activities. Almost one third of 8th-grade students and 12th-grade students report that they rarely write lengthy answers to reading questions on tests.
Students do not have access to key science and technology learning opportunities. For example, 72% of eight-grade science students say that they are not taught engineering and technology.

Too many students report that they are not learning during class and do not understand their teacher’s questions. For example, about 50% of 12th-grade math students reported that they feel they are always or almost always learning in their math class. One third of 12th graders and one fourth of middle school students report that they hardly ever clearly understand what their math teacher asks.

Students from disadvantaged backgrounds are less likely to understand their teachers’ questions. For example, 74% of higher income fourth-grade students report that they often or always understand what their science teacher is saying compared with just 56% of lower income fourth-grade students.

sec.p: Based on these results, the researchers recommend that (a) policymakers continue to push for higher, more challenging standards, (b) the nation needs to identify ways to provide all students with the teachers and the teaching that provide more rigorous learning opportunities, and (c) researchers and educators should continue to develop and use student surveys.

sec.title: Progress on Science Standards
sec.p: Using a representative sample of 122,000 eight-graders who participated in the 2011 NAEP science assessment, the National Center of Education Statistics reported that among the 47 states that chose to participate in both years, scores in 16 states were higher in 2011 than in 2009 and remained the same in the rest of the states (National Center for Education Statistics, 2011). Although there was a significant change in the gender gap where males score about 5 points higher than females, the racial/ethnic gap also narrowed between White, Black, and Hispanic students. However, while students scored higher in 2011 than in 2009, there was no significant change from 2009 in the scores for students at the 90th percentile. In terms of teaching and learning, students whose teachers reported using more hands-on projects scored higher than students who participated less frequently in hands-on projects. Moreover, students who report doing science-related activities that are not for schoolwork score higher on the NAEP. However, a more recent report on science standards across states found great variability in their quality (Lerner et al., 2012). Using a common grading metric, researchers who were supported by the Thomas B. Fordham Institute evaluated each state’s science standards, “content and rigor” and “clarity and specificity” (Lerner et al., 2012, p. 5). They found that the average grade across all states was a “C” with 26 earning a “D” or below and only 2 (California and District of Columbia) earning an “A.” They identified these areas where states fail to measure up: an undermining of evolution, a propensity to be vague, poor integration of scientific inquiry, and limited integration of math with science. Clearly, education of our high-performing science students needs more support from teachers, standards, and assessments.

sec.title: Text Complexity
sec.p: One of the Common Core State Standards in English language arts places a great emphasis on increasingly complex texts. Writers of the standards say that whereas the complexity of texts in entry-level college courses and workplaces has held steady or increased slightly, the complexity of texts used in high schools has declined over the past few decades (Rothman, 2012). For this reason, the Common Core State Standards lay out a three-part model for examining text complexity that includes quantitative analysis using readability formulas and a qualitative analysis that includes examinations of the readers and the tasks. Quantitative formulas measure text complexity using vocabulary and syntax. For example, texts that contain many unfamiliar words and contain long, complicated sentences are more difficult to understand than texts using common words and shorter sentences. The qualitative analysis examines factors such as knowledge demands placed on the readers and the levels of meaning. For example, a text is more complex if more of the information needed is implicit rather than explicit or has deeper meanings. In addition to these qualitative and quantitative analyses, teachers need to determine their students’ interests and background knowledge to select texts that the students comprehend.

sec.title: More Imaginative Children
sec.p: Students in 2008 are more imaginative than their counterparts in 1985 report researchers (Russ & Dillon, 2011) in the Creativity Research Journal. They videotaped nearly 900 children ages 6 to 10 for 5 min each as they talked while playing with three blocks and two hand puppets. They then scored each video for the child’s imagination, emotional expression, actions, and storytelling using the Affect in Play Scale (APS). Across 14 studies spanning 23 years, children showed no difference in the organization or emotional engagement of their play or storytelling, but the imagination quality showed a marked increase. The children also expressed less negative feelings in play and a wide range of positive emotions to tell their stories and organize their thoughts. The authors concluded that even though children’s playtime has been restricted, they have found ways to continue to pretend whether in more imaginative tasks within the curriculum or at home. They further explained that children might gain cognitive skills from using technology where they once got it from acting out situations in play.

sec.title: Rural Connections for Gifted Students
sec.p: The Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth has initiated a new program, Rural Connections, which provides scholarships for low-income, rural students to attend the center’s 3-week residential program during the summer (Courrégé, 2012). The program, which is supported by the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation, has been operating since 1980 and is intended to give students a taste of college life—academically and socially. Students choose from an array of courses such as engineering and design course to studying the classics. Students also have opportunities to interact with other students who are interested in academics and are similar to themselves. The center does research and offers online courses, family academic programs, and counseling. It is part of a larger consortium of talent search programs, which include Duke Talent Identification Program, Center for Talent Development at Northwestern, the Belin-Blank Academic Talent Search, and the Carnegie Mellon Institute for Talented Elementary and Secondary Students.

sec.title: K-8 Publishers’ Criteria for Common Core State Standards in Mathematics (CCSSM)
sec.p: The writing team of the CCSSM (2012) has developed a document that is intended to provide a guide to states and districts in evaluating and selecting curricular materials. The document has been endorsed by the Council of the Great City Schools, Council of Chief State School Officers, National Association of State Boards of Education, National Governors Association, and Achieve. The design principles should focus on three areas:

list-item.p: Focus. The scope of content in each grade needs to be narrowed so that students focus more deeply on the concepts.
Coherence. Each individual content standard is connected across grades and between topics.
Rigor. Each major work at each grade level needs to emphasize conceptual understanding, procedural skill and fluency, and applications.

sec.p: Using these principles, the rubric for evaluating math materials includes the following criteria:

list-item.p: Focus on “major work.” Students and teachers spend the large majority of their time on the major work of each grade.
Focus in early grades. Materials do not assess topics prior to the indicated grade level.
Focus and coherence through supporting work. Supporting content does not detract from the focus on the major work.
Rigor and balance. Materials and tools develop students’ conceptual understanding, fluency, and applications.
Consistent progressions. Materials are consistent with the progressions in the standards.
Coherent connections. Materials include learning objectives that are shaped by the CCSSM cluster headings and connect two or more clusters in a domain.
Practice–content connections. Materials connect content standards to practice standards.
Focus and coherence via practice standards. Materials promote focus and coherence by connecting practice standards with content emphasized in the standards.
Careful attention to each practice standard. Materials attend to the full meaning of each practice standard.
Emphasis on mathematical reasoning. Engage students in attending to the specialized language of mathematics, problem solving, and constructing and critiquing viable arguments

sec.title: Physics Games
sec.p: Are you interested in physics? Use your knowledge to play these online physics-based games. You can build bridges, use trajectories to make basketballs go into baskets, and use strategy to place explosives on structures to detonate them. There are games in categories such as construction, platform, projectile, and more. You can even add your favorite games to your own website by pasting the computer code that is provided with each game.

sec.title: National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) for Kids
sec.p: Check out the NASA’s site for kids. You can find out your weight on any planet or even the comet or the sun. Do you want to build your own space exploration fleet? Print the instructions and model parts for nanorovers, satellites, and more directly from this site. You can also explore the “Eyes on the Solar System” link that takes you to a three-dimensional (3D) environment full of real NASA mission data. You will need Java software to be able to view this part of the site.

sec.title: National Geographic Videos for Kids
sec.p: Visit this cool website for footage of octopi, “exploding” toads, a bat falcon, acacia ants, daddy long legs, fish symbiosis, fishy disguises, and hairy cucumbers. You can watch a bear meeting, watch humpback whales feed in Alaska on the crittercam, or see alligator hatchlings. You can find out what is inside a golf ball, see the final moments of the National Geographic Bee, or see highlights from the Canadian rain forest, Diwali festival of lights, Machu Picchu, Mount Fiji, or Aboriginal rock art. My Shot Minute features pictures of nature submitted by kids. There are also videos in Spanish and Mandarin.

sec.title: SAT Question of the Day
sec.p: The SAT is designed to assess students’ readiness for college. This site features a new practice question every day. It may be a reading or mathematics question, and students can select the answer. If an incorrect answer is selected, the site prompts the student to try again. When the correct answer is chosen, an explanation is given. Information about the number of responses and the percentage that were correct is provided for each question. This site familiarizes students with the different types of questions they will need to be prepared to answer. Students can see the last seven questions that have been featured on the site. They can also print or email the questions. Students can log in and save their answers or track their progress.

sec.title: Prezi Presentations
sec.p: Use this website to create presentations that are more interactive than a regular PowerPoint presentation. You can create an account at this site and use 100 MB of online storage space. You can choose from templates to get started. You can zoom in or out, insert content, or position and resize content and text. During the presentation, you can click on and zoom in a particular item on each slide.

boxed-text.title: Notable
boxed-text.p: The Association for the Gifted (TAG), a division of the Council for Exceptional Children, presented the leadership award to Dr. Diane Montgomery, a regents professor in Oklahoma State University College of Education’s School of Applied Health and Educational Psychology. Dr. Montgomery has served on the TAG Board for more than 20 years as president, vice president, past president, children’s advocacy network coordinator, and chair of a variety of TAG committees.

The National Association for Gifted Children has published two books that examine the use of the Common Core State Standards with gifted and advanced learners. Using the Common Core State Standards for English Language Arts (ELA) With Gifted and Advanced Learners (VanTassel-Baska, 2013) provides example activities for typical and advanced learners that focus on ELA reading standards for literature, ELA reading standards for informational text, ELA standards for writing, and ELA standards for speaking and listening. Using the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics With Gifted and Advanced Learners (Johnsen & Sheffield, 2013) is copublished with the National Council of Supervisors of Mathematics and the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. This book also includes example activities for typical and advanced learners that focus on patterns, fractions, geometry, and measurement and data. Both books are published by Prufrock Press (http://www.prufrock.com).

The Reading Like a Historian curriculum, designed by the Stanford History Education Group, is a set of 75 free secondary school lessons in the U.S. history. The program focuses heavily on four key skills: “sourcing,” to gauge how authors’ viewpoints and reasons for writing affect their accounts of event; “contextualization,” to get a full picture of what was happening at the time; “corroboration,” to help students sort out contradictory anecdotes and facts; and “close reading,” to help them absorb text slowly and deeply, parsing words and sentences for meaning. For example, each lesson begins with a question and is followed by students reading a group of primary source documents. Using these reading materials, students develop interpretations about the events that must be supported by the evidence that they have read. Instead of being the primary source of information, the textbook is used as a teacher and student resource. Lessons are designed to fit within the 50-min class period. To access these resources, visit http://sheg.stanford.edu/?q=node/45

Over the past 2 years, the Association for the Gifted, a division within the Council for Exceptional Children, has published a series of books that focuses on gifted students who are underserved in gifted programs. Books in the series include RtI for Gifted Students (M. R. Coleman & Johnsen), Effective Curriculum for Underserved Gifted Students (Stambaugh & Chandler), Effective Program Practices for Underserved Gifted Students (Adams & Boswell), A Teacher’s Guide to Working With Children and Families From Diverse Backgrounds (Roberts & Jolly), The Underachieving Gifted Child: Recognizing, Understanding, and Reversing Underachievement (Siegle), and Diversity in Gifted Education (Felder & Taradash). All of these books are published by Prufrock Press (http://www.prufrock.com).

Even though boys tend to perform higher on the ACT test than girls, the National Center for Education Statistics reported that 59% of girls as compared with 53% of boys expected to complete a bachelor’s or graduate/professional degree. The gender pattern held for both White and Black students. Senior girls with college plans were also more likely than boys to consult a counselor, teacher, or coach for information on college outcome requirements. To view the full report about Higher Education: Gaps in Access and Persistency Study, visit http://nces.ed.gov/pubs2012/2012046.pdf

The Cities for Education Entrepreneurship Trust is a coalition of 23 city-based foundations, nonprofits, and mayors’ offices that support efforts to improve local schools. These foundations share ideas and guide leaders who are interested in learning instructional models, school choice, and leadership development. They facilitate the growth of entrepreneurial education initiatives that share high-impact reform strategies between cities and help communities design and launch city-based initiatives that champion education innovation and reform. They are supported by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the Joyce Foundation, and the Carnegie Corporation of New York. For more information, visit http://cee-trust.org

President Obama signed a new initiative to improve educational outcomes for African Americans. The White House Initiative on Educational Excellence for African Americans will work across federal agencies and with partners and communities nationwide to produce a more effective continuum of education programs for African American students to fully prepare them for high school graduation, college completion, and productive careers. The executive order also creates the President’s Advisory Commission on Educational Excellence for African Americans to aid and advise the work of the initiative. The commission will advise the president and the education secretary on the development, implementation, and coordination of resources aimed at improving educational opportunities and outcomes. The initiative is housed within the Department of Education. To read the entire executive order, visit http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/07/26/executive-order-white-house-initiative-educational-excellence-african-am

The Parent Power Index is an interactive online tool from the Center for Education Reform designed to show parents how much influence they have over certain aspects of their children’s education in their state. Each state summary includes fast facts such as the graduation rate, average SAT and ACT scores, national assessment results, per-pupil funding, transparency, and public school enrollment. To access the index, visit http://www.edreform.com/in-the-states/parent-power-index/

The U.S. Department of Education is providing academic and financial checklists for elementary, middle, and high school students and parents on its website, StudentAid.gov. Each of the checklists provides information for parents about ways to support their child in their studies, where to establish a college savings account, and how to apply for financial aid. There is also a checklist for adult students who have never been to college but are interested in finding a new career path. To access all of the checklists, visit http://studentaid.ed.gov/sites/default/files/college-prep-checklist.pdf

The Upper West Side Speyer Legacy School in New York City will open a new middle school for gifted and talented students next year and move the entire school to a bigger space, a school representative said. After leading the Hollingworth Preschool at Columbia’s Teachers College for many years, Coulianos said she finally heeded the call of parents who wanted to continue their children’s education in her style of an intellectually advanced curriculum with an emphasis on creative thinking. Coulianos opened Speyer Legacy in 2009 with her colleague, Dr. Esther Kogan, and several founding families.

Venture Lab, a new online course on a new online platform at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)/Stanford, hosts five courses this fall on entrepreneurship, education, creativity, and finance. The course joins people from dozens of countries and enables them to collaborate on group projects. For example, three men in India devised a way of connecting Indian musicians, audiences, and venues; a team with members in Germany, the United Kingdom, and Russia developed a mobile app for buying and selling locally designed products; and four Americans and a Pakistani created a search engine to find online classes. For more information about Venture Lab, visit http://www.vlab.org/

A new organization comprising business leaders, art professionals, educators, and others is working to educate the governments, the public, and the media about the need to return arts to the national curriculum. They suggest that the arts is a necessary adjunct to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM; e.g., Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Mathematics [STEAM]). Arts education is a key to creativity, which is essential to innovation and new industries. For more information about STEAM, visit http://steam-notstem.com/

A total of 22 young people were named as 2012 Davidson fellows. Among the fellows are students who have conducted research about infinitesimal Cherednik algebras (David Ding), specific proteins relationship to drug-resistant breast cancer drugs (Manoj Kanagaraj), algae-derived biofuels (Sara Volz), and causes of Parkinson’s disease (Michael Yan). The Davidson Fellows program offers US$50,000, US$25,000, and US$10,000 college scholarships to students 18 or younger who have created significant projects that have the potential to benefit society in the fields of science, technology mathematics, literature, music, and philosophy.

The seventh annual Closing the Expectations Gap report by Achieve analyzes how all states are aligning college- and career-ready (CCR) standards in English and mathematics with policies that send clear signals about what it means to be academically prepared for college and careers after high school graduation. The report also details states’ policy progress on the CCR agenda as well as efforts to implement those policies. To access the full report, visit http://www.achieve.org/ClosingtheExpectationsGap2012
